history.content:
Well definitely take 61c as it's a lower div requirement. On top of 61c and 110, if you seem up to you can take 126. Since you took 70 and 170 freshman year you should be okay. 126 is a good probability class, can help prepare you for quant probability interviews, introduces a bit of machine learning, and is an important prereq for 189 which you can take next spring if you feel like.

Wait, I just saw that you haven't taken ee16b. That's also an essential requirement so your schedule should really include ee16b and 61c. Then I suppose take either math 110 or eecs 126 with the 2 classes. Either should be fine with the math maturity you seem to have. 110 gives a strong backbone in linear algebra, more so than ee16a/b, which should help for 189.

-----------------------

If you want to go into ML, in my opinion you can put off 61C (I'm a second year and still haven't taken it). I'd recommend 16B and 126 for next semester, along with 110. 

-----------------------

OP here: How important is 16B as a course, it seems to cover a lot of EE related stuff that I don't really have an interest in. Would it be possible just to self-learn the math required for ML and put off 16B for a while? Also how would the schedule of 126 + 110 + 1 more tech compare to my past schedules because it seems like quite a bit of work?

Well definitely take 61c as it's a lower div requirement. On top of 61c and 110, if you seem up to you can take 126. Since you took 70 and 170 freshman year you should be okay. 126 is a good probability class, can help prepare you for quant probability interviews, introduces a bit of machine learning, and is an important prereq for 189 which you can take next spring if you feel like.

Wait, I just saw that you haven't taken ee16b. That's also an essential requirement so your schedule should really include ee16b and 61c. Then I suppose take either math 110 or eecs 126 with the 2 classes. Either should be fine with the math maturity you seem to have. 110 gives a strong backbone in linear algebra, more so than ee16a/b, which should help for 189.

-----------------------

If you want to go into ML, in my opinion you can put off 61C (I'm a second year and still haven't taken it). I'd recommend 16B and 126 for next semester, along with 110.

Well definitely take 61c as it's a lower div requirement. On top of 61c and 110, if you seem up to you can take 126. Since you took 70 and 170 freshman year you should be okay. 126 is a good probability class, can help prepare you for quant probability interviews, introduces a bit of machine learning, and is an important prereq for 189 which you can take next spring if you feel like.

Wait, I just saw that you haven't taken ee16b. That's also an essential requirement so your schedule should really include ee16b and 61c. Then I suppose take either math 110 or eecs 126 with the 2 classes. Either should be fine with the math maturity you seem to have. 110 gives a strong backbone in linear algebra, more so than ee16a/b, which should help for 189.

children.subject: OP: 61B + 170 is pretty chill I think another tech in addition to them is manageable (assuming no breadths, cuz those are really time consuming for me). There is some content overlap, but for the most part the two courses are quite different. I personally don't think 61B is needed at all for 170 (70 is an absolute must though).

Most students would find taking 61B before 170 very helpful. You are expected to have a strong understanding of asymptotics including Big O and Omega (which are taught in 61B). In addition graphs, Shortest paths (dijkstra's), MSTs are all covered in both 61B and 170. Having been exposed to these concepts as well as a bit of algorithm design in 61B beforehand will help with the rigor of 170.

Oh and the relevant 170 topics taught in 61B are covered in the second half of the course (asymptotics are taught mid-way) while all these topics form the early part of 170 so taking them concurrently won't yield much benefit.
Question to the original poster: how was 61B with 170? Will I need 61B knowledge early in the class, or are the two manageable concurrently?

In response to the OP's followup, 126 is a difficult class, you will have to spend 25-30 hrs a week on it for homework, lab, lecture, and textbook reading. I haven't taken 110 so I can't really comment on that, but from what I've heard its not too bad. You should be able to add another tech to that if you don't have any large commitments outside of school. 

For 16b I guess you can put it off if you plan on self-learning all the linear algebra, but if you have space for another technical you should add that over a class like 61c since its more applicable.

history.content:
I am currently an EECS freshmen and I basically have no idea what I want to take next Fall except for Math 110. I am fairly sure I am going to industry, aiming for either Quant, SWE, or research teams like Uber ATG, but I'm considering getting a Masters first. I am planning to focus on ML in the future, but I'm not sure if I want the heavy workload this early on. I would ideally want a schedule that helps me work towards these goals but still leaves me free time to explore other things. As for my background: 

Tested out of: R1A, Math 1A, Math 1B

Semester 1: CS61A, EE16A, CS70

Semester 2: CS170, CS61B, Philosophy 12A (PNP), Psych 150 (PNP), CS195 (PNP)

Summer: Math 53, R1B

I did well both semesters. I found my first semester really chill, second semester was hard at times but still overall manageable. Ideally, a workload in between the difficulty of what I had these 2 semesters would be ideal. Courses I'm currently considering on top of Math 110 include CS61C, EE126, Stat 134, CSW186, but I don't know that many courses. Any recommendations for what I should take?
history.subject: Struggle Choosing Classes
